race.name: Ruby Roubaix
race.tagline: Northeast Nevada gravel in remote Ruby Mountains near Elko.

climate.description: High altitude with variable mountain conditions.

terrain.surface: Mountain and high desert gravel roads. Significant elevation with remote wilderness setting.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Tiny grassroots Nevada event. Remote Ruby Mountains setting but extremely limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Ruby Roubaix is a tiny grassroots gravel race in the remote Ruby Mountains of northeast Nevada. Lamoille is a tiny town with minimal amenities. The mountain scenery is beautiful and the altitude challenge is real, but it's an extremely small field with basic organization. It's an honest local event for hardy Nevada cyclists who want a remote wilderness gravel ride.
weaknesses: Very small field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A tiny local gravel race in remote Nevada wilderness. Perfect for locals or those seeking a remote Ruby Mountains experience. Not worth the long drive for most riders unless you're combining with Nevada tourism.

final_verdict.one_liner: Tiny grassroots Nevada wilderness ride with extremely remote location.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in Nevada or seeking extreme remote wilderness. Not worth the long drive for the race alone.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Nevada events: other regional events. For similar remote wilderness vibes: other Great Basin events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Lamoille has very limited lodging. Elko (20 min) has more options.
logistics.food: Tiny town with minimal dining. Bring your own.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in Ruby Mountains.

course_description.character: Mountain gravel through Ruby Mountains wilderness.
course_description.signature_challenge: High altitude climbing in remote Ruby Mountains.

non_negotiables.why: Racing at 6000-8000+ feet requires altitude acclimatization or preparation.
5000 feet of climbing requires strong aerobic capacity.
Extremely remote location and minimal support mean managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Ruby Mountains gravel at 6000-8000+ feet.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Tiny grassroots event in remote Lamoille.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup directions remain 'find the schoolhouse on race day.' No airport info, vague lodging suggestions to 'check out Elko,' zero parking details. The research data still reads like someone forgot to finish building the website.

length.explanation: Four distance options from 22 to 120.5 miles accommodate different abilities, with time estimates ranging from 'under 2 hours' for the Pleasant Valley Loop to '8-12 hours' for the Ruby Loop. Elite locals completed the long course 'in just over 8 hours moving time while training for the Nevada State 508.'

technicality.explanation: Course conditions span 'well compacted dirt, washboards, loose sand-gravel, some areas of well compacted rocky road' with 'several significant segments with energy-sucking loose sand-gravel.' Organizers warn that 'anything less than a 35mm tire will result in a lot of bad words and a very long day.'

elevation.explanation: The Harrison Pass descent features 'the steepest downhill grades (up to 10%) on a twisting gravel road with choppy washboards and loose gravel.' Secret Pass and Ruby Valley climbs create challenging elevation profiles through northern Nevada's high desert terrain at the base of the Ruby Mountains.

climate.explanation: Late June conditions range from 40-60°F starts to afternoon highs in the 80s-90s, with typical SSW winds that 'can be any direction.' Organizers note the weather variability: 'It can be hotter, and it is not unknown to be snowing on the summer solstice.'

altitude.explanation: Lamoille sits at the base of the Ruby Mountains with routes climbing through Secret Pass and Harrison Pass summits. The high desert altitude compounds difficulty across the vast expanses of lightly traveled roads through Ruby Valley and Pleasant Valley terrain.

adventure.explanation: Routes traverse the Ruby Lake National Wildlife Refuge, Lee, Jiggs, and Ruby Valley on mixed terrain through spectacular Ruby Mountains backcountry. Potential water crossings 'depending on winter snowpack and spring storms' add variability to the remote northern Nevada adventure that marketing grants aim to 'draw them off I-80.'

prestige.explanation: Sixth-year Rotary Club fundraiser founded by retired pediatrician Dr. Kevin Dinwiddie, modeled after Reno's former 'Edible Pedal' event. The 2023 field of 165 registered riders reflects regional appeal rather than national recognition, with proceeds funding youth programs and scholarships.

race_quality.explanation: Fondo format allows riders to 'race it or ride it—you pick' with aid stations at 12-18 mile intervals providing 'water, electrolytes, Hammer Nutrition products' and basic mechanical support. Mandatory rest stop check-ins ensure safety in remote terrain where organizers 'don't want to lose anyone in wild Nevada.'

experience.explanation: Harrison Pass summit creates a 'point of no return' where 'once you descend the east side of the pass the easiest way out is to finish the loop.' Required gear lists include tubeless backup tubes and chain tools, emphasizing self-sufficiency through energy-sucking loose gravel sections.

community.explanation: Community volunteers 'greet you at stops along the routes with big smiles, two-way radios, water, and snacks specific to the needs of cyclists.' Post-race atmosphere includes Las Brisas taco truck, microbrews, and massages, with proceeds supporting Elko County scholarships and youth leadership programs.

field_depth.explanation: Results show local winners like Jared Kosanovic and Mark Freedle across distance categories, with E-bike divisions alongside traditional timing. Mcschne10's first-race excitement and the recreational-focused fondo format indicate community participation over competitive depth.

value.explanation: Four distance options access remote Ruby Mountains terrain most cyclists never experience, with entry including Hammer Nutrition goody bags, lunch, beverages, and post-race amenities. Charitable proceeds fund community scholarships and youth programs while delivering gravel adventure through spectacular Nevada backcountry.

expenses.explanation: Elko area lodging avoids major city pricing, with camping options at Thomas Canyon Campground or dispersed sites in Lamoille Canyon. Remote location limits race weekend inflation, though riders need tubeless setups and self-sufficiency gear for the challenging loose gravel segments.
